Daniel Wills: Labor must rebuild after the Jay era  The Advertiser

Jay Weatherills exit from state politics will mark the end of an era for Labor.

item.description:
Jay Weatherill accuses Malcolm Turnbull of politicising South Australia’s blackout  The Australian

Jay Weatherill has accused Malcolm Turnbull of intervening to politicise a state emergency after South Australias devastating statewide blackout in 2016, saying ...

item.title: Jay Weatherill quits: Quietly spoken but cunning as a fox - The Advertiser
item.description:
Jay Weatherill quits: Quietly spoken but cunning as a fox  The Advertiser

On numbers alone, Jay Weatherill should never have become the states 45th premier.

item.title: Labor looks to replace Weatherill in SA - SBS News
item.description:
Labor looks to replace Weatherill in SA  SBS News

The South Australian Labor Party is expected to open nominations to find a replacement for Jay Weatherill, after the former premier announced his resignation.

item.title: Union chief in line for seat as Weatherill quits parliament - The Australian
item.description:
Union chief in line for seat as Weatherill quits parliament  The Australian

Jay Weatherill, who yesterday announced his resignation from state parliament, has ruled out entering federal politics, saying he could think of nothing worse.

item.title: Former SA premier Jay Weatherill to retire from politics - ABC News
item.description:
Former SA premier Jay Weatherill to retire from politics  ABC News

Former South Australian premier Jay Weatherill has announced he will be stepping away from the limelight after 16 years in the state's Parliament.

item.title: Video - The Australian

Video  The Australian

Former South Australian premier Jay Weatherill has announced his retirement from state politics after serving 16 years in the sector. Mr Weatherill led the state ...

item.title: Weatherill quits parliament - The Australian
item.description:
Weatherill quits parliament  The Australian

Jay Weatherill, who yesterday announce­d his resignation from state parliament, has ruled out enteri­ng federal politics, saying he could think of nothing worse. The 54-year-old former South Australian Labor premier said he had “run my race” and it was “time to pass the baton on”. “I don’t like the culture and the dynamic of federal politics,” Mr Weatherill said. “I have no plans other than looking after two little girls and a wife, and some ageing parents. “Politics is always about the ­future and I could not see myself running in 2022. Former leaders hanging around politics doesn’t have a...

item.title: Cheek, mischief and the final day of Jay - The Advertiser
item.description:
Cheek, mischief and the final day of Jay  The Advertiser

There’s a bit more rattiness and cheek than usual, and the people who are meant to be keeping the joint running in good order let a bit more mischief go than usual. This Thursday had more nostalgia and magnanimity than is usual as MPs farewelled the grand old building for summer, and a past premier said goodbye to the place forever. Former premier Jay Weatherill’s decision to pull the pin on a 16-year career, almost all of which was spent as a member of Cabinet, surprised no one. It seemed destined to come — the only question had been around timing. And it triggered speeches from political ...

item.title: ‘I’m proud of my achievements’ - The Australian
item.description:
‘I’m proud of my achievements’  The Australian

Former South Australian Labor premier Jay Weatherill will retire from state politics and outline his exit plans during today’s final state parliamentary sitting day of the year. Mr Weatherill, 54, has sat on the opposition backbench since leading Labor to defeat at the March state election. The former lawyer entered parliament in 2002 and went straight into cabinet, serving in various ministerial positions until he took over as premier in 2011 from Mike Rann following a cross-factional deal orchestrated by the union boss Peter Malinauskas. Mr Malinauskas, who Mr Weatherill later brought int...

item.title: Former SA premier Jay Weatherill retires (full speech) | ABC News - ABC News
item.description:
Former SA premier Jay Weatherill retires (full speech) | ABC News  ABC News

Jay Weatherill, the former Labor South Australian premier, announces his retirement from state politics. The former lawyer was first elected in 2002 and was directly appointed to premier Mike Rann's cabinet. He replaced Mr Rann as premier in 2011. Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-12-06/former-sa-premier-jay-weatherill-to-retire-from-politics/10588600 For more from ABC News, click here: http://www.abc.net.au/news/ Subscribe to us on YouTube: http://ab.co/1svxLVE You can also like us on Facebook: http://facebook.com/abcnews.au Or follow us on Instagram: http://instagram.com/ab...

item.title: Jay Weatherill quits politics - The Advertiser
item.description:
Jay Weatherill quits politics  The Advertiser

Mr Weatherill chose State Parliament’s final scheduled sitting day of the year to confirm his exit, after 16 years of service, which will trigger a by-election in his safe western suburbs seat of Cheltenham. Flanked by his wife and two daughters in a press conference yesterday, Mr Weatherill said he would devote himself to family life and had no plans for the next phase in his career. Mr Weatherill said he was proud of how the State Government under his leadership handled the fallout from the shelving of the Olympic Dam expansion and announcement that Holden’s Elizabeth factory would close ...

item.title: Owner of Elon Musk's big SA battery escaped fine for missed deadline - ABC News
item.description:
Owner of Elon Musk's big SA battery escaped fine for missed deadline  ABC News

By Nick Harmsen Tesla boss Elon Musk famously delivered on a promise to build it within 100 days or do it for free, but a new report has revealed the owner of South Australia's giant battery escaped a government fine for missing a key testing deadline. The 100-megawatt lithium-ion Tesla battery, the most powerful of its kind in the world, has been operating alongside French company Neoen's Hornsdale Wind Farm near Jamestown in South Australia's north since the beginning of last summer. The battery was a key element of the former Weatherill government's $550 million energy plan, aimed at red...

item.title: SA Liberal MPs cross the floor to oppose controversial mining bill - ABC News
item.description:
SA Liberal MPs cross the floor to oppose controversial mining bill  ABC News

By Tom Fedorowytsch and Cassandra Hough A rebel Liberal MP "had no choice" but to cross the floor over debate on a contentious mining bill in South Australia's Parliament, leading to him being labelled as "destructive" and a "bloody fool". South East MP Nick McBride, along with fellow Liberals Fraser Ellis, Dan Cregan and Steve Murray, yesterday sided with Labor on three consecutive votes to postpone debate on the amendments to the Mining Act until next year. Mr McBride said farmers wanted the right to lock their gates to mining companies, but his own Government was not listening. "We had e...

item.title: Home battery scheme to shore up power supply ahead of summer - ABC News
item.description:
Home battery scheme to shore up power supply ahead of summer  ABC News

South Australia's Energy Minister has warned there is still a 10 per cent chance of load-shedding blackouts this summer, ahead of warmer temperatures in the state this week. Key points: - The SA Government says it is working to combat the blackout risk ahead of summer - Very hot weather is expected in parts of SA and Victoria later this week - A home battery and solar loan and grant scheme is now available in SA Parts of South Australia and Victoria are expecting a sweltering start to November, with temperatures forecast to reach the low-40sin regional areas. The Bureau of Meteorology expec...

item.title: Adelaide tram plan still on Feds’ radar - The Advertiser
item.description:
Adelaide tram plan still on Feds’ radar  The Advertiser

Former premier Jay Weatherill’s AdeLINK program included new tram lines to North Adelaide and Norwood. The latest official Priority List from Infrastructure Australia, which provides independent advice to the Federal Government, includes AdeLINK as a priority initiative for which a business case must be developed before it can proceed. Former Labor treasurer Tom Koutsantonis said AdeLINK should go ahead because it would benefit all South Australians. “Investing in trams not only creates jobs and breathes new life into our streets and suburbs – but encourages more South Australians to use pu...

item.title: Victorian Greens push for banks to pay more with controversial levy - ABC News
item.description:
Victorian Greens push for banks to pay more with controversial levy  ABC News

Victorian treasury coffers would be boosted by $1.5 billion if the state backed a bold Greens policy to slug the big banks with a state-based levy, according to the new parliamentary budget office. Under the Greens' plan, Victoria would impose a separate 0.015 per cent quarterly bank levy on the state's share of bank liabilities that are already subject to the commonwealth's bank levy. The proposal is a copy of the former South Australian Labor government's state-based bank levy. Former premier Jay Weatherill ultimately dumped his proposed bank levy because it was blocked by the Coalition a...

item.title: 'Appalling' hypocrisy: Labor cries foul over SA Premier's Kiwi consultant $100,000 payday - ABC News
item.description:
'Appalling' hypocrisy: Labor cries foul over SA Premier's Kiwi consultant $100,000 payday  ABC News

The South Australian Government is spending almost $100,000 of taxpayers' money to bring a New Zealand consultant into Premier Steven Marshall's department for a month's work, in a move the Opposition says shows "appalling" hypocrisy. Key points: - State Government is spending $91,500 in taxpayers' money to bring in a NZ consultant - Wayne Eagleson will spend 30 days advising the public service over a five-month period - Opposition says the move shows "appalling" hypocrisy A contract signed in June will see Wayne Eagleson — chief of staff to former New Zealand prime ministers John Key and B...

item.title: SA Government and Murray-Darling Basin Royal Commissioner at odds over legal stoush - ABC News
item.description:
SA Government and Murray-Darling Basin Royal Commissioner at odds over legal stoush  ABC News

A war of words has arisen between the State Government and the Murray-Darling Basin Royal Commissioner over a legal push to compel public servants to give evidence to the inquiry. Key points: - Statement from SA Attorney-General claims a push to compel public servants to give evidence had been dropped - She now expected the High Court proceedings to be discontinued - Commissioner Bret Walker SC said the statement was "wrong in every particular" South Australian Attorney-General Vickie Chapman has issued a statement that the move would be dropped. But Commissioner Bret Walker has said she is...

item.title: Jay Weatherill’s less-than-Remarkable day bushwalking - The Advertiser
item.description:
Jay Weatherill’s less-than-Remarkable day bushwalking  The Advertiser

Mr Weatherill was trekking with his family in Mount Remarkable National Park when he fell and injured himself about 12pm on Sunday. It is understood the incident happened in an area with no mobile phone reception and the former Labor leader’s family had to leave him to find a signal so they could call for help. Local CFS and SES volunteers, as well as ambulance, police crews and park rangers, were sent to retrieve Mr Weatherill. He took to social media on Monday to share his ordeal. “On Sunday I fell while bushwalking with my family through Hidden Gorge in Mt Remarkable National Park and br...

item.title: Former SA premier rescued in rugged terrain after breaking leg on bushwalk - ABC News
item.description:
Former SA premier rescued in rugged terrain after breaking leg on bushwalk  ABC News

By Isabel Dayman and Rebecca Puddy Former premier Jay Weatherill has been spending more time with his family now he is on the opposition's backbench, however his adventures this weekend might not have delivered the kind of break he was anticipating. Mr Weatherill was bushwalking with his wife, Melissa and daughters Lucinda and Alice on Sunday, when he fell and broke his leg in rugged terrain in a gorge three hours from Adelaide. The ensuing medical evacuation from Hidden Gorge in Mount Remarkable National Park took two hours, with Mr Weatherill being carried by stretcher. He took to social ...

item.title: SA federal infrastructure money a fraction of what was promised - ABC News
item.description:
SA federal infrastructure money a fraction of what was promised  ABC News

It's been revealed only a fraction of the $1.8 billion in federal infrastructure money promised for South Australia in last night's federal budget will flow over the next four years. Key points - $1.8b for SA road and rail announced ahead of budget - Only $162m included in federal budget - Industry bodies slam budget as 'smoke and mirrors' The state and federal governments have spent this week heralding the $1.8 billion funding, which includes $1.2 billion for upgrading South Road, $220 million to fully electrify the Gawler rail line and $160 million towards duplicating Port Augusta's Joy B...

item.title: 'Steves' match number of women in SA's cabinet - ABC News
item.description:
'Steves' match number of women in SA's cabinet  ABC News

We already know there are more male CEO's named John, Peter and David than there are female CEO's, and in South Australia it's become apparent there are just as many "Steves" as there are women in cabinet. External Link: Nick Harmsen tweet: Liberal MP Vincent Tarzia elected Speaker unopposed. As tradition dictates, he’s dragged to the chair by the Premier and Opposition Leader While the state's new-look parliament is younger and more gender-diverse its proliferation of the namesake was noted during the first day back at Parliament. A total of 47 new and returning Lower House MPs, and 22 new...

item.title: Liberal-linked adman appointed to SA tourism job by Premier - ABC News
item.description:
Liberal-linked adman appointed to SA tourism job by Premier  ABC News

South Australia's Premier has appointed a Liberal-linked adman to the board of the SA Tourism Commission (SATC), after the company he founded missed out on a lucrative tourism advertising contract to an interstate firm. Steven Marshall has ordered the appointment of Andrew Killey, the co-founder of advertising agency KWP!, to a one-year term on the board of the SATC. Last week, the Premier sought an explanation from the tourism agency after it awarded its advertising work to Melbourne-based TBWA, when its current contract with Adelaide-based KWP! expires. KWP! also tendered for the contract...

item.title: Malinauskas signals shift on ICAC secrecy, unveils SA shadow cabinet - ABC News
item.description:
Malinauskas signals shift on ICAC secrecy, unveils SA shadow cabinet  ABC News

South Australia's new Labor leader, Peter Malinauskas, has signalled his party may support legislation to allow open ICAC hearings, a marked shift from the party's policy under former premier Jay Weatherill. Mr Malinauskas revealed his position while unveiling his shadow cabinet line-up. Changes to stance on ICAC signalled Mr Malinauskas said he had called the Independent Commissioner Against Corruption, Bruce Lander, shortly after his election by the ALP caucus yesterday and would meet the commissioner next week to discuss whether he should be granted the right to conduct maladministration...

item.title: Labor stalwart retreats to focus on seat - The Advertiser
item.description:
Labor stalwart retreats to focus on seat  The Advertiser

The Labor MP held the southern seat of Mawson by just 115 votes against his Liberal challenger Andy Gilfillan after a major boundary redistribution. Mr Bignell confirmed to The Advertiser that he had told incoming Labor leader Peter Malinauskas that he did not want a place in the shadow ministry, which is expected to be announced on Monday, April 9. He is not seeking any other position, such as Whip or Parliamentary Secretary. “I know what I’m like. (In shadow cabinet) I’d be travelling to Mt Gambier, Port Pirie, Port Augusta, Port Lincoln, Whyalla ... that’s what I’ve always done,” he said...

item.title: Cloud clears over 10 suspended TAFE SA courses - ABC News
item.description:
Cloud clears over 10 suspended TAFE SA courses  ABC News

TAFE SA lost sight of the quality of its training courses as it pursued a "single-minded focus on cost-cutting", according to an independent review of the training provider commissioned by the former Labor government. The review written by independent consultants the Nous Group was commissioned in the wake of last year's damning federal audit, which found major problems with TAFE SA's assessment practices in 16 courses. The audit plunged TAFE SA into crisis, prompted the government to sack the organisation's chief executive and chairman, and left a cloud over 10 qualifications, which were s...

item.title: Maybe Writers’ Week boss was right — to a point - The Advertiser
item.description:
Maybe Writers’ Week boss was right — to a point  The Advertiser

After all, more than 62 per cent of voters didn’t put the Libs as their first choice for the House of Assembly last Saturday. It was their third-lowest share of the first-preference vote in history. But low expectations are great for politicians because it doesn’t take much to raise the bar. And Treasurer Rob Lucas did a little bit of that this week, when he showed a distinct lack of confected outrage over a Facebook tirade against the Liberals by newly-appointed Adelaide Writers’ Week director Jo Dyer. Yes, one of the nation’s more clever minds did one of the dumbest things imaginable: she...

item.title: Weatherill to resign as leader after SA Labor loss - ABC News
item.description:
Weatherill to resign as leader after SA Labor loss  ABC News

Defeated premier Jay Weatherill says he will resign as Labor leader after losing this weekend's election to the Liberals. Key points: - Jay Weatherill says a new leader will be decided soon - He says he has "zero ambition" to join the Federal Parliament - Steven Marshall says getting the state "back on track" will be his focus Mr Weatherill visited Government House late on Sunday morning to officially resign as premier, where he told reporters he planned to see out his term in State Parliament. "I'm looking forward to that, being the state member for Cheltenham. It's a fascinating seat, it ...

item.title: Jay Weatherill heckled during energy press conference - ABC News
item.description:
Jay Weatherill heckled during energy press conference  ABC News

South Australian Premier Jay Weatherill has been heckled by an environmental protester at his final election campaign press conference — exactly one year after he delivered his now infamous take down of Federal Energy Minister Josh Frydenberg. Mr Weatherill chose to revisit the event in his final campaign pitch, as he unveiled a deal for South Australia to once again build the world's biggest battery, this time at Port Augusta. Mr Weatherill even presented a commemorative mug of the press conference to the householder Geoff Perkins. The pair then watched the key moments on an iPad, with Mr ...

item.title: SA Liberal leader promises 'new dawn' after claiming election victory - ABC News
item.description:
SA Liberal leader promises 'new dawn' after claiming election victory  ABC News

Liberal leader Steven Marshall has declared a "new dawn" in South Australia after claiming victory in the SA election, with his party poised to form government for the first time in 16 years. Key points - Liberal leader Steven Marshall claims victory in SA election - Mr Marshall declares a "new dawn" after 16 years of Liberal opposition - Labor leader Jay Weatherill congratulates Mr Marshall - SA Best looks unlikely to secure a seat as Liberal Vincent Tarzia sees off Nick Xenophon Mr Marshall arrived to a rock star's welcome at the Liberal election function, walking to the stage to the soun...

item.title: Analysis: It could be D-Day for more than one SA political leader - ABC News
item.description:
Analysis: It could be D-Day for more than one SA political leader  ABC News

After what has seemed like an almost endless campaign, the South Australian election is finally here. A new way to stay across the SA election ABC News on Messenger can tell you about all the big moments from the campaign trail. Tap to find out more. And it's somewhat of a D-Day for all of the political leaders — Jay Weatherill, Steven Marshall and Nick Xenophon. Whatever happens tonight — whether a clear win or a hung parliament — the political career of more than one could be over. Premier Mr Weatherill is often noted as having an incredibly charmed run. First elected when Labor seized go...

item.title: SA Liberals tight-lipped on Musk battery storage plan - ABC News
item.description:
SA Liberals tight-lipped on Musk battery storage plan  ABC News

The fate of South Australia's deal with Elon Musk's Tesla to supply free household batteries to 50,000 homeowners remains uncertain, following the electoral defeat of SA Labor. Former premier Jay Weatherill announced the policy in February with much fanfare, declaring it would create the world's "largest virtual power plant". Under the plan, more than 1,000 housing trust homes were to receive the scheme over the following year, with another 49,000 properties to get solar panels and Tesla batteries over the next four years. Photo: SA Premier Steven Marshall says his Government will honour ex...

item.title: When will we find out who SA's premier is? - ABC News
item.description:
When will we find out who SA's premier is?  ABC News

The polls have closed and vote counting is beginning across South Australia, where the parties today made their final pitches to voters after a four-week election campaign. The day unfolded not entirely without controversy, with more claims of dirty tricks and underhanded tactics. Key moments - Polling closed at 6:00pm - Postal votes can be returned up to a week after election day - Final results will not be declared until votes have been received and counted - That is expected to happen in the week of March 26 Labor raised eyebrows with its choice of T-shirt colours for its volunteers hand...

item.title: Accusations of public servant sackings and spending money like 'drunken sailors' - ABC News
item.description:
Accusations of public servant sackings and spending money like 'drunken sailors'  ABC News

Labor has accused the Liberal Party of planning to sack teachers and police officers, while the Liberal Party has accused Labor of spending like "drunken sailors", as the two major parties release their election promise costings, two days out from the polls. A new way to stay across the SA election ABC News on Messenger can tell you about all the big moments from the campaign trail. Tap to find out more. Labor's capital works spending amounts to nearly $2 billion on projects like the elimination of seven level crossings, and tram line extensions to Norwood and North Adelaide. While much of ...

item.title: South Australia to house world's biggest battery (again) - ABC News
item.description:
South Australia to house world's biggest battery (again)  ABC News

Elon Musk's Tesla battery in South Australia's Mid-North will no longer be the world's most powerful — with a new, bigger battery being built at Port Augusta. Photo: Jay Weatherill at the launch of the Tesla lithium ion battery in December. (ABC News: Nick Harmsen) The new battery will be built by Whyalla steelworks owner Sanjeev Gupta, who secured a $10 million loan from the State Government through its Renewable Technology Fund. The British billionaire, who purchased the steelworks last year though his company Liberty House, also bought a controlling stake in South Australian renewable fi...

item.title: Political mavericks shake South Australia out of its two-party torpor - CNN
item.description:
Political mavericks shake South Australia out of its two-party torpor  CNN

It was billed as a provincial election, in a part of the country that rarely receives any national attention. But on Saturday, 1.7 million South Australians will vote in what many are describing as the most exciting electoral race in a generation, as maverick insurgents look to overturn the state's traditional two-party political system. In the months before the vote, it was assumed it would be a contest between the ruling state Labor Party, which has held government for the last 16 years, and the Liberal opposition, which famously lost an unlosable election in 2014 when it won the popular ...

item.title: SA's unpredictable poll to be decided by record number of voters - ABC News
item.description:
SA's unpredictable poll to be decided by record number of voters  ABC News

Polling booths are open across South Australia as a record number of voters decide the next government in what many see as the most unpredictable election in the state's recent history. Labor is trying to secure a fifth consecutive term in office, after 16 years in power, as it is challenged by Steven Marshall's Liberals and Nick Xenophon's new party SA Best. Anti-Xenophon material was being handed to voters at polling booths in the Hartley electorate, where the SA Best leader is running for the Lower House. The Australian Hotels Association has been campaigning against Mr Xenophon on the i...

item.title: 12 questions you might still be wondering about the SA election - ABC News
item.description:
12 questions you might still be wondering about the SA election  ABC News

In the lead up to polling day, we've been running Curious Campaign, a project that collects your burning questions about the March 17 election. In this edition, we are answering 12 questions you might still be wondering. 1. How do you vote when you're overseas? If you are heading overseas before Saturday, then you can until March 16. Ian, who asked the question, left for an overseas holiday before pre-polling began, so he has two options. Firstly, you can vote at selected international locations, in Europe, Asia, the United States and New Zealand. There is also the possibility to postal vot...

item.title: Live: Polls close in SA as three-way contest begins - ABC News
item.description:
Live: Polls close in SA as three-way contest begins  ABC News

Polls have closed in South Australia and counting across the state is beginning. With Labor's Jay Weatherill shooting for a fifth term in government, the Liberal Party's Steven Marshall hoping to govern in his own right, and Nick Xenophon seeking to shake things up with SA Best, the election will likely be a tight three-way contest for power. Follow the results and developments in our blog. External Link: SA Election Blog, Saturday March 17

item.title: Why South Australians are older, poorer and on their way interstate - The Guardian
item.description:
Why South Australians are older, poorer and on their way interstate  The Guardian

This weekend South Australians go to the polls, and after 16 years in office the ALP is facing a pretty tough task to retain government – although, with the introduction of Nick Xenophon’s SA Best party into the mix, no one is all that sure of what will happen. But whoever wins government will preside over an economy that has struggled behind the rest of the nation since the early 1990s. As one who grew up in country South Australia and who, despite not having lived in the state for nearly a quarter of a century, still supports the Crows, Adelaide United, and the Adelaide Strikers, and gets...
